title: Capitol Report: Elizabeth Warren asks for probe of tax-time financial products

thread.title: Capitol Report: Elizabeth Warren asks for probe of tax-time financial products
thread.title_full: Capitol Report: Elizabeth Warren asks for probe of tax-time financial products

text:
Getty Images for TurboTax TurboTax products sit on display at Costco. 
Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat from Massachusetts, on Tuesday asked the General Accountability Office to review tax-time financial services used by millions of Americans. 
In a letter to the GAO, Warren, Sen. Tammy Duckworth, a Democrat of Illinois, and Sen. Al Franken, a Democrat from Minnesota, asked the government watchdog to examine the scope and impact of tax-time financial products by companies such as Intuit Inc. INTU, +0.60% parent of TurboTax, and H&R Block HRB, +0.59% , including whether fees they charge are “reasonable and transparent.” 
The senators also raised concerns about possible excessive fees for refund-related products. 
They cited the growing use of “refund anticipation checks,” a temporary bank account set up so that the IRS can directly deposit a refund into the account. Tax preparation fees, plus a fee for the account setup, are then deducted by firms. 
These checks cost consumers an average of $25 to $60 for federal refunds and were the source of $648 million in taxpayer fees in 2014, the letter said. The checks have replaced refund anticipation loans, which were subjected to a government crackdown over their fees. 
Opinion: The share of tax dollars coming from you is growing — and the share from companies is shrinking 
Last week Warren introduced legislation calling for the Internal Revenue Service to establish a free online tax preparation and filing service that would effectively cut out the middleman firms. 
“The tax preparation industry wants to keep Americans locked into a difficult and expensive tax-filing process — that’s how they turn big profits,” Warren said in a statement. 
Don’t miss: Americans get an ‘F’ on income tax quiz 
For its part, H&R Block said in a statement it “welcomes independent review of any of our products and services.” 
The company said it was “proud” to provide clients a variety of products and services at tax time and beyond. More from MarketWatch
